Appendix 3  9 
TRANSACTION TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.   Justification 
 
1.  The Health Services Sector Development Program (HSSDP) will help Papua New Guinea 
(PNG)  strengthen  health  services  through  policy  reforms  and  direct  investments  in  health 
systems. A diagnostic assessment of the coverage, financing, and quality of health services is 
required to ensure that the interventions are designed for maximum impact. The Government of 
PNG will require transaction technical assistance (TRTA).  
 
2.  The HSSDP design will ensure that the program’s scope, coverage, and policy reforms 
align with the PNG National Health Plan 2010–2020 and Development Strategic Plan (2010–
2030).1 Lessons from the ongoing Asian Development Bank (ADB) Rural Primary Health Services 
Delivery Project will inform the design process.2 The TRTA will involve continuous stakeholder 
consultations to determine the scope of interventions.  
 
B.   Major Outputs and Activities 
 
3.  The TRTA team will (i) prepare a situation analysis of effective health service coverage; 
(ii)  determine  the  scope  and  feasibility  of  project  investments,  including  capacity  building, 
medicine supply, and civil works; (iii) prepare cost estimates and a financing plan; (iv) analyze the 
project’s financial and economic viability and sustainability; and (v) determine implementation 
arrangements. It will prepare the project administration manual (PAM) incorporating the above 
and other relevant aspects. Major outputs are summarized in Table A3.1.

C.   Cost Estimate and Proposed Financing Arrangement 
 
4.  The TRTA is estimated to cost $0.8 million and will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s 
Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-6). The detailed cost estimate is in Table A3.2.

D.  Consulting Services 
 
5.  The TRTA will be carried out by a team of consultants, totaling 27 person-months of 
consulting  services  (18  international  person-months  and  9  national  person-months).  The 
consulting team will comprise a public health specialist (the team leader), health governance and 
reforms specialist, medical supplies expert, financial specialist, procurement specialist, gender 
and social safeguards specialist, resettlement and/or land acquisition specialist, environmental 
safeguards specialist, health system governance and public finance management specialist, and 
a  health  coordinator.  The  summary  terms  of  reference  by  consultant  are  in  paras.  6–12. 
Consultants will be recruited using individual consultant selection in accordance with ADB’s 
Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2013, as amended from time to time) and engaged on 
output-based contracts.

6.  Public  Health  Specialist  (Team  Leader)  (international,  5  person-months)  The 
international team leader shall have (i) a postgraduate degree in public health, (ii) at least 10 
years of relevant experience in health systems and/or public health, (iii) experience in leading 
project preparation of similar health sector interventions, and (iv) experience with ADB and/or 
other multilateral development bank (MDB) projects. Experience in PNG is an advantage. Tasks 
include (i) leading a health services situation analysis to examine issues, strategies, policies, and 
institutional factors related to access, equity, and quality; (ii) recommending improved operational 
mechanisms and facilitating coordination with government agencies and other stakeholders to 
identify key reforms; (iii) assessing institutional capacity and developing a phased capacity 
building program; and (iv) supporting the identification of priority provinces for project investments, 
institutional strengthening, and capacity building. Outputs will include (i) inception, interim, and 
final  reports;  (ii)  stakeholder  consultations  and  workshops;  and  (iii) required  ADB  program 
documentation following ADB guidelines. 
 
7.  Health Governance and Reforms Specialist (international, 2 person-months). The 
consultant shall have (i) a post graduate degree in public health, law or a similar field and (ii) at 
least 10 years of experience in assessing reforms in the health sector (human resources, medical 
supplies, hospital management). Experience in PNG is an advantage. The consultant will (i) 
review current health acts and laws that impact the health sector in PNG; (ii) analyze areas of 
overlap and governance and institutional risks and (iii) contribute to the health sector assessment.  
 
8.  Medical supplies expert (international, 2 person-months). The consultant shall have 
(i) a graduate degree in public health, pharmacy, procurement, supply chains or a similar field 
and (ii) at least 7 years of experience in procurement and supply chains for medical supplies. 
Based on existing reviews the consultant will (i) developed a proposed model for medical 
procurement  using international best practice and (ii) design a phased approached from changing 
from a ‘push’ to a ‘pull’ medical supplies system.  
 
9.  Financial  Specialist  (international,  2  person-months).  The  financial  management 
specialists should have (i) graduate degrees in financial management or a similar field, (ii) 
recognized professional accountancy qualifications, and (iii) experience with ADB and/or other 
MDB projects. Experience in PNG is an advantage. Key roles include (i) assessing the financial 
management capacity of the various involved departments, (ii) preparing funds flow diagrams, 
and (iii) defining financial procedures and delineating responsibilities between agencies involved 
in the financial management of loan proceeds.  
 
10.  Procurement  Specialist  (international,  2  person-months).  The  procurement 
specialists  should  have  (i)  graduate  course  in  public  procurement  or  a  similar  field;  (ii) 
demonstrated  experience  in  conducting  procurement  and  procurement  assessments,  and 
designing  and  delivering  procurement  training;  and  (iii)  experience  applying  ADB/MDB 
procurement guidelines is mandatory. Experience in PNG is an advantage. Key roles include (i) 
assess the procurement capacity of the executing and implementing agencies; (ii) prepare the 
procurement plan for the proposed project in accordance with government regulations and ADB’s 
procurement guidelines; (iii) prepare master bidding documents for the project; (iv) conduct a 
procurement risk assessment and prepare the procurement risk assessment and management 
plan, and (v) train the executing and implementing agencies and project management unit staff in 
procurement and consulting services procedures. 
 
11.  Gender and Social Safeguards Specialist (international, 2 person-months). The 
specialist will have (i) a graduate degree in social sciences or a similar field; and (ii) at least 5 
years of experience in gender and social development assessments, ideally in the context of

12  Appendix 3 
health intervention application in social services. Key roles include (i) providing a summary 
assessment of health gender issues, (ii) collecting gender-disaggregated baseline data to be 
monitored during project implementation, (iii) identifying interventions to address gender gaps and 
promote benefits to women and other disadvantaged groups in the proposed project areas, (iv) 
confirm whether ADB's social safeguard requirements must be triggered, (v) develop a detailed 
gender action plan with clear timelines and measurable targets, and (vi) facilitate the integration 
of gender indicators into the project monitoring and evaluation systems. The specialist will also 
prepare a stakeholder engagement, participation, and communication plan. 
 
12.  Resettlement and/or Land Acquisition Specialist (international, 1 person-month). 
The specialist will have (i) a graduate degree in land rights, sociology, or a similar field; (ii) at least 
8  years  of relevant  experience;  and (iii)  experience  with  ADB  and/or  other  MDB  projects. 
Experience in PNG is an advantage. The specialist will prepare a resettlement framework 
according to the requirements of the ADB Safeguard Policy Statement (SPS) (2009) and pertinent 
government policies. One or more subprojects will be appraised before the sector investment is 
approved, and relevant documentation, including resettlement plans or due diligence reports, will 
be prepared as required. The specialist will evaluate potential direct or indirect resettlement 
impacts or impacts on indigenous peoples, if any, associated with the supported policy actions. A 
matrix of each policy action’s potential impacts, together with appropriate mitigation measures, 
will be prepared, with a qualitative indication of the likely order of magnitude of each impact and 
brief reasons for the judgment. Safeguards documents should follow government and ADB SPS 
2009 requirements.  
 
13.  Environmental  Safeguards  Specialist  (international,  2  person-months).  The 
specialist must have (i) at least a bachelor’s degree in environmental management, engineering, 
or science; and (ii) at least 8 years of experience in implementing environmental safeguards, 
ideally within the health sector. Experience in PNG is an advantage. The specialist will be 
responsible for developing an environmental assessment and review framework for the sector 
project, and will prepare at least one environmental assessment of a subproject identified during 
preparation. The framework will comply with the  SPS 2009, as well  as national  laws and 
requirements relating to environmental assessment, to facilitate compliance with environmental 
requirements during project implementation. 
 
14.  Governance  and  Public  Finance  Management  Specialist  (national,  5  person-
months). The consultant shall have (i) a degree in public health, (ii) at least 10 years of relevant 
experience in health systems, and (iii) management experience in health systems in PNG. The 
consultant will (i) undertake a situation and gap analysis of the governance of health service 
delivery, including the government system for budget execution, accounting, and auditing; (iii) 
engage in consultations with stakeholders to identify the scope and feasibility of different models 
of governance and fund flow for health service delivery including potential partnerships, target 
provinces and innovations; and (iv) analyze the technical feasibility of the project investments and 
how they support the policy matrix.  
 
15.  Health Coordinator (national, 4 person-months). The coordinator will have (i) at least 
a bachelor’s degree in public health or a similar field, and (ii) at least 7 years of experience working 
in the health sector in PNG. The coordinator will support liaising with relevant stakeholders, as 
well as providing any support required by the consultants.  
 
E.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
16.  ADB will be the executing agency for the TRTA, and the Departments of Treasury,

Appendix 3  13 
 
Planning, Health, and Finance will be the implementing agencies. The implementing agencies will 
assist the TRTA consultants with liaising, data gathering, preliminary analyses, report writing, and 
organizational support for seminars and meetings, as reasonably required to carry out their tasks. 
Disbursements  will  be  made  in  accordance  with  the  Technical  Assistance  Disbursement 
Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time).
